words.def: The 4-foot-diameter (1.2 m) circle in the house. It surrounds the centre area called the button. It is used as a visual aid only – there is no extra score for placing a stone within it
words.name: 4-foot

words.def: The 8-foot-diameter (2.4 m) circle in the house. It is used as a visual aid only – there is no extra score for placing a stone within it; generally not actually painted – it appears as the empty space between the 12-foot and 4-foot rings
words.name: 8-foot

words.def: The 12-foot-diameter (3.7 m) circle outermost in the house; a stone completely outside this circle cannot score
words.name: 12-foot

words.def: On a hit, refers to the shooter hitting the object stone on the opposite side from where the broom was placed. Since this imparts less speed to the object stone and takes less speed away from the shooter, it is a very efficient way of making a tick. This is seldom used for normal hits since it is harder to execute, unless necessary because a guard prevents using the other turn
words.name: Across the face

words.def: A very rare and extremely difficult shot in which a stone is delivered so that it will come to rest behind another stone already in play, created the same effect as if one stone had been frozen to the other
words.name: Anti-freeze

words.def: Synonymous with gripper
words.name: Anti-slider

words.def: Temporary curling ice made quickly on a hockey rink or the like, most often used by curling clubs without dedicated curling facilities; usually of lower quality than that of a dedicated facility, but when created for televised events or events with large numbers of spectators, the ice quality can rival or even exceed that of a dedicated facility
words.name: Arena ice

words.def: A double or triple where the shooter ends up coming back up the rings
words.name: Around the horn

words.def: The portion of the 4 foot ring behind the tee line
words.name: Back 4

words.def: The portion of the 8 foot ring behind the tee line
words.name: Back 8

words.def: The portion of the 12 foot ring behind the tee line
words.name: Back 12

words.def: The border at the extreme ends of the sheet
words.name: Back board

words.def: A team's third and skip, considered as a unit.
words.name: Back end

words.def: Delivery speed required for a stone to come to rest in the back half of the house
words.name: Back-house weight

words.def: The line right behind the house. If a rock completely crosses the back line, it is removed from play
words.name: Back line

words.def: The portion of the house behind the tee line
words.name: Back of the House

words.def: Synonymous with back 12
words.name: Back ring

words.def: A board or other object behind the hack, used to stop moving stones; referred to as "bumper" in Canada
words.name: Barrier

words.def: Delivery speed that should come to rest against the barrier behind the hack. Synonymous with board weight.
words.name: Barrier weight

words.def: The traditional name for the device used to sweep ahead of a moving stone. A broom.
words.name: Besom

words.def: A stone that barely touches the outside of the house, i.e. the 12-foot ring
words.name: Biter

words.def: A piece of equipment used to determine whether or not a stone is a biter; also known as a 'biter bar'
words.name: Bite stick

words.def: An end in which no stones are touching the house, and thus no points are scored; in regular play the team that has the hammer retains it for the next end. In skins games, the skin for a blanked end is carried over. To "blank an end" means to intentionally leave no stones in the house so as to retain the hammer.
words.name: Blank end

words.def: Deliberately creating a blank end for the purposes of retaining the last rock advantage for the next end of play
words.name: Blanking an end

words.def: A shot delivered with heavy weight and high velocity. A blast is usually intended to remove many stones from play or is used to break up and move around clustered stones. "Playing the blast" into a large cluster of stones is often a last resort shot to get the rocks split up when there are no other viable shots available.
words.name: Blast

words.def: Throwing a stone with enough speed that it will come to rest in an area just behind the hacks – about 6 feet behind the house. Synonymous with barrier/bumper weight.
words.name: Board weight

words.def: Scots for league match, this is the term used for a curling tournament. Compare "spiel"
words.name: Bonspiel

words.def: A failed corner freeze where the shooter rolls open
words.name: Bounce

words.def: The Canadian men's curling championship, held annually since 1927
words.name: Brier

words.def: An implement with which players sweep the ice to make a stone travel farther and curl less; though brushes have almost completely replaced brooms, the traditional name remains
words.name: Broom

words.def: See stacking the brooms
words.name: Broomstacking

words.def: Broom / Sweeping
words.name: Brush / brushing

words.def: A short raise
words.name: Bump

words.def: The barrier
words.name: Bumper

words.def: Synonymous with barrier/board weight.
words.name: Bumper weight

words.def: A rock that is hidden behind another rock, usually a guard, making it difficult for a curler to hit with a delivered rock. Also called "covered"
words.name: Buried

words.def: To accidentally touch a moving stone; the opposing skip has the option to remove the burned stone, or leave it where it comes to rest
words.name: Burn

words.def: The centre (bullseye) of the house; sometimes called the 1-foot circle
words.name: Button

words.def: When the skip holds the broom where he/she wants the person delivering the stones to aim. When the skip is delivering, the third calls the shot
words.name: Calling the shot

words.def: A series of eight premier men’s and women’s events that feature Canada’s deepest and strongest curling fields
words.name: Grand Slam of Curling

words.def: A tournament with significant entry fees and large prizes, sometimes part of a charity event; despite the large prizes, cashspiels are not the premier events in curling
words.name: Cashspiel

words.def: A guard that is placed directly on the centre line, in front of the house; usually played by the team that does not have the hammer
words.name: Centre guard

words.def: A line running lengthwise down the centre of the ice, used as a visual aid; some sheets do not have a centre line, or do not have one between the hog lines
words.name: Centre line

words.def: A takeout that hits a rock at an angle
words.name: Chip

words.def: When a played stone strikes the edge of another stone and moves to another position in play
words.name: Chip and lie / chip and roll

words.def: Series of rocks in the house arrayed from front to back mostly along the centre line.
words.name: Christmas Tree

words.def: Grazing a stationary stone without significantly moving it; but enough to alter the path of the shooting rock[citation needed]
words.name: Chroming the Rock

words.def: A flashy but low-percentage shot. Also Trick shot
words.name: Circus shot

words.def: To brush the ice lightly in front of a moving rock to remove any debris and ensure a correct line; less vigorous than a sweep
words.name: Clean

words.def: The location of the curling rink; most players usually refer to it as "The Club"
words.name: Club

words.def: Any shot that curls around another rock
words.name: Come-around

words.def: Going into the final end
words.name: Coming home

words.def: A takeout shot that is slow enough that the sweepers have relative control over its curl; faster than board weight, but slower than normal takeout weight
words.name: Control weight

words.def: A type of guard that is off to the side of the house; usually employed when a team has the hammer and needs to score multiple points
words.name: Corner guard

words.def: A stone in the house lying closer to the centre than any of the opponent's stones. Each counter scores one point at the completion of an end.
words.name: Counter

words.def: Protection given to a rock by a rock in front of it
words.name: Cover

words.def: Movement of a moving rock away from a straight line; as a verb, to play at curling
words.name: Curl

words.def: General term for player involved in a curling team; also known as a "soofter" in the UK
words.name: Curler

words.def: A team sport which involves sliding granite stones on ice and sweeping in front of them with brooms to direct them to desired placements
words.name: Curling

words.def: Synonymous with club
words.name: Curling club

words.def: A participation souvenir, generally worn on a sweater; there is a sub-culture at any major bonspiel built around trading pins. Most curling clubs and many tournaments produce one, and they are usually not awards
words.name: Curling pin

words.def: A device that permits a player to deliver a stone while standing upright; generally used by older players, these are legal in most games.
words.name: Curling stick

words.def: A rock completely covered by another rock (often a guard) such that no part is visible
words.name: Dead buried

words.def: Synonymous with no handle
words.name: Dead handle

words.def: Process of throwing a stone
words.name: Delivery

words.def: Scoring 2 points in an end
words.name: Deuce

words.def: A call given by the skip for the sweepers to stop sweeping a rock; a rock that dies is a rock that stops moving
words.name: Die!

words.def: State of a sheet of ice where the sides are slightly elevated compared to the center, so that a cross section of the ice would look like a cross section of a dish; this sometimes happens near the end of a week-long tournament because the pebbling motion tends to apply more pebbles to the side, while sweeping during games happens more often near the center and wears down the ice more in that region; when there is a dish, rocks will curl more towards the center and less away from the center
words.name: Dish

words.def: A takeout shot in which two other stones are removed from play; a shot in which the delivered stone and one other stone are removed is not a double takeout
words.name: Double takeout / Double

words.def: When two rocks are frozen, hitting the top rock at an angle creates a drag effect that affects the direction of the second rock; the friction between the two frozen rocks makes the first rock "drag" the second rock slightly towards the same direction; hitting the top rock on the right makes the bottom rock move more to the left while hitting it on the left makes it move more to the right
words.name: Drag

words.def: A shot that lands in play without hitting another stone out, as opposed to a takeout shot. Also refers to a game, e.g., “We have a draw at 7:00 p.m. tonight.”
words.name: Draw

words.def: A shot in which the played stone pushes a stone straight forward into the house
words.name: Draw raise

words.def: Person who assigns teams to different sheets, sets starting times, assigns players to teams in casual play, etc.
words.name: Drawmaster

words.def: Delivery speed required for a stone to come to rest in the house
words.name: Draw weight

words.def: During delivery of a stone, the thrower accidentally pushes the stone off-course with their turning motion; often the result of using the arm to shove the stone, and usually causes a missed shot
words.name: Dump the handle (also Flip or Turn-Out/Turn-In)

words.def: Command – called out by the skip to tell the sweepers to ease off their sweeping of a rock but to continue sweeping it lightly and slowly.
words.name: Easy

words.def: An end where all eight stones score for one team – a very rare occurrence.
words.name: Eight-ender

words.def: Similar to an inning in baseball; in an end, each team throws 8 rocks, 2 per player in alternating fashion; tournament style games usually run for 10 ends; games played at the club level usually run for 8 ends. Prior to the latter half of the twentieth century, a game consisted of 12 ends played in full.
words.name: End

words.def: Equivalent to an extra inning in baseball; in the event of a tie after the prescribed number of ends, extra ends are played until the tie is broken.
words.name: Extra end

words.def: A defect in the ice which causes stones thrown in that area to curl negatively
words.name: Fall

words.def: As the stone is sliding down the sheet, it curls negatively, i.e., the opposite direction than it is supposed to
words.name: Falling

words.def: The amount of sideways movement in the last 3 meters (10 feet) or so of a rock's path; can be used as a verb ("it needs to finish") or a noun ("there's lots of finish in that spot")
words.name: Finish

words.def: To completely miss an attempted takeout; the rock passes through the house without touching any rocks at all
words.name: Flash

words.def: The player throwing the last two rocks for a team; since the skip almost always throws the last two rocks, this term is rarely used
words.name: Fourth

words.def: Area between the hog line and the tee line, excluding the house. Evolved from the Moncton Rule.
words.name: Free-Guard Zone

words.def: The rule that states that an opponent's rock resting in the free-guard zone cannot be removed from play until the first four rocks of an end have been played
words.name: Free-Guard Zone Rule

words.def: A precise draw weight shot where a delivered stone comes to rest against a stationary stone, making it nearly impossible to knock out
words.name: Freeze

words.def: A team's lead and second, considered as a unit
words.name: Front end

words.def: Delivery speed required for a stone to come to rest in the front half of the house
words.name: Front-house weight

words.def: The portion of the house closer to the hog line
words.name: Front of the House

words.def: Synonymous with top 12
words.name: Front ring

words.def: Buildup that can occur on ice surfaces when there is excessive humidity in the air; tends to makes stones stop faster and curl less
words.name: Frost

words.def: Bonspiel oriented to recreational/fun play, often shorter duration games, and may have unusual formats
words.name: Fun Spiel

words.def: A rock that is placed in front of another rock to protect it from being knocked out by the other team, or placed with the intent to later curl another rock around it and thus be protected; typically placed between the hog line and the very front of the house
words.name: Guard

words.def: A rubber or other material attached to a curling shoe to improve traction on the ice; also known as an anti-slider; see Slider
words.name: Gripper

words.def: Similar to a starting block in track and field, the foothold device where the person who throws the rock pushes off for delivery
words.name: Hack

words.def: The weight required to deliver a stone in order that it travels to the hack at the far end
words.name: Hack weight

words.def: A slower played takeout that, because of the reduced speed, curls more and therefore can reach opponent stones that are hidden behind a guard
words.name: Hackweight takeout

words.def: The last rock in an end – a huge advantage; the team with the last rock is said to "have the hammer"
words.name: Hammer

words.def: The part of the stone held by the player; used to describe the desired direction of rotation of the handle (and therefore the stone) upon release in a given delivery; "Losing the handle" refers to a rock which stops curling or which changes direction of curl while moving; See also No Handle, Reverse Handle, Straight Handle.
words.name: Handle

words.def: Each team traditionally shakes hands with each member of the opposing team at the end of a match as a sign of goodwill. Unlike other sports, curlers can, and are often encouraged to, forfeit the game early out of sportsmanship if the score is badly lopsided or if a team runs out of stones. To signal their forfeit, the losing team shakes the hands of the other team. This can simply be called "shaking", as in "the Smith team shook after 7 ends".
words.name: Handshake

words.def: Command – along with "hurry" – shouted by the skip to tell the sweepers to sweep harder and faster
words.name: Hard!

words.def: A stone that is thrown harder than required and will probably slide too far
words.name: Heavy

words.def: Slow ice on which stones take more initial force to travel a similar distance as on fast (keen) ice (see keen ice)
words.name: Heavy ice

words.def: Any shot where the aim is to move another stone; the opposite of a draw
words.name: Hit

words.def: A takeout rock that, after making contact with another rock, slides (rolls) into a designated area
words.name: Hit and roll

words.def: A takeout where the played stone stays in the spot where it made contact with the stationary stone; also called 'hit and stick' or a 'nose hit'
words.name: Hit and stay

words.def: Another term for take-out weight
words.name: Hit weight

words.def: See "hogged rock"
words.name: Hog

words.def: The line which the stone must completely cross to be considered in play
words.name: Hog line (far)

words.def: The line by which the stone must be clearly and fully released by the thrower
words.name: Hog line (near)

words.def: Failure to release a stone before crossing the near hog line; a stone in violation is immediately removed from play
words.name: Hog line violation

words.def: A shot that comes to rest short of or on the far hog line and is removed from play
words.name: Hogged rock

words.def: See "hogged rock"
words.name: Hogger

words.def: The three concentric circles where points are scored
words.name: House

words.def: see hard! (often said together: "hurry hard!")
words.name: Hurry!

words.def: Adjustment to the crosswise distance between the skip's broom and the desired target area; for example, a player who feels that the skip's broom is too close to the target might request "more ice"
words.name: Ice (more, less, too much, not enough)

words.def: Person who is responsible for maintaining the ice, duties include, but are not limited to pebbling and scraping the ice
words.name: Icemaker

words.def: A shot where the delivered stone hits another stone near the outer edge of the sheet at an angle, making the shooter roll into the house; one of the most difficult curling shots, usually done as a last resort when there are no other options
words.name: In-off

words.def: A shot in which the handle of the stone is rotated across the body (the elbow is rotated "in" to the body); for a right-handed thrower, an in-turn is clockwise, and the opposite for a lefty
words.name: In-turn

words.def: Another term for narrow
words.name: Inside

words.def: Fast ice on which stones travel greater distances with less force than required for heavy ice (see heavy ice)
words.name: Keen ice

words.def: A delivered stone that is intentionally wobbled to compensate for water, slush or snow on the ice surface
words.name: Kizzle kazzle

words.def: When the rotation of a stone is very slow, i.e., less than one full rotation during the stone's slide; often the result of thrower error, they will usually curl more than a properly delivered stone; may turn into a No Handle or Reverse Handle
words.name: Lazy handle

words.def: The player who throws the first two rocks for a team
words.name: Lead

words.def: The count of the number of stones of one colour closest to the centre of the button, closer than the innermost stone of the other colour. When a team "lies X" or "is lying X", that number of its stones are, at that moment, closer to the button than any opposition stone; were the end to finish then, the team would score that number of points.
words.name: Lie / Lies / Lying

words.def: The path of a moving stone; a 'good' line indicates it is headed where it was intended to go; a 'bad' line has deviated
words.name: Line

words.def: A stone that is not thrown hard enough
words.name: Light

words.def: Many clubs offer a Little Rocks program for children, with rocks that are roughly half the weight of regular 44 lb. rocks. Curlers generally move onto full-sized rocks around the ages of 10 to 12.
words.name: Little rocks

words.def: A rock that is "losing the handle" refers to a rock which loses its rotation or which reverses its rotation while moving
words.name: Losing the handle

words.def: Synonymous with no handle
words.name: Lost turn

words.def: Last Stone in the First End; in every other end, the last stone (or hammer) is determined by the scoring in the previous end. In the first end, some other system (coin toss, draw contest, record comparison) must be used to determine the advantage of the hammer.
words.name: LSFE

words.def: A type of delivery, mostly found in Manitoba, where the body is kept very low to the ground and the leading leg is tucked underneath the body and to the side; this type is delivery is particularly efficient for hits but makes draws slightly tougher to execute, with the shoulders not being as straight and the eyes being closer to the ice
words.name: Manitoba tuck

words.def: The player who discusses strategy with the skip behind the house and holds the broom while the skip throws his rocks; usually plays third; also known as vice-skip or vice
words.name: Mate

words.def: Equipment used to determine which of two or more stones is closest to the centre when they are too similar to know with visual inspection
words.name: Measure stick

words.def: A stone delivered off the broom too close to the desired target and therefore likely to curl past it
words.name: Narrow

words.def: A shot in which the player curls the stone in the opposite direction in which the stone is expected to curve, due to significant defects in flatness of the ice surface; for example, if the curvature of the ice causes all stones to drift sharply to the right, a skip may request the shooter to aim to the left of the desired location and curve the stone to the left as well.
words.name: Negative ice

words.def: Called during the sweep to indicate the stone needs to curl and the sweepers should stay off the rock
words.name: Never

words.def: A term used by some Manitoba teams, similar to Control weight
words.name: Nice weight

words.def: A rock delivered without a turn, usually done in error; stones thrown without a handle often follow an unpredictable path
words.name: No handle

words.def: Normal takeout weight; faster than control weight, but slower than peel
words.name: Normal weight

words.def: The point on a rock closest to the shooter. A "nose hit" would be hitting the rock at this point, avoiding a roll.
words.name: Nose

words.def: A call given by the skip for the sweepers to stop sweeping a rock
words.name: Off!

words.def: An incorrectly aimed shot; opposite of on the broom
words.name: Off the broom

words.def: A rock that is not obscured by another rock from the shooter's perspective; a skip will often ask the shooter how "open" a certain rock appears from the hack, with the rock being totally open, partially obscured (such as "half open") or completely covered; also, a term for any shot not involving going around a guard: an open takeout, an open draw, etc.
words.name: Open

words.def: A correctly aimed shot that starts out directly at the broom held by the skip; opposite of off the broom
words.name: On the broom

words.def: A situation in which a team that is behind in the score no longer has enough stones between those in play and those yet to be played to make up the deficit; the outcome is now certain, and the game usually ends with a handshake once a team is out of stones.
words.name: Out of stones

words.def: Another term for wide
words.name: Outside

words.def: A shot in which the handle of the stone is rotated away from the body – the elbow is rotated "out" from the body; for a right-handed thrower, an out-turn is counter-clockwise, and the opposite for a lefty
words.name: Out-turn

words.def: A rock
words.name: Pancake

words.def: Small droplets of water intentionally sprayed on the ice that cause irregularities on the surface, allowing the rocks to curl. Also a verb; the action of depositing water droplets on the ice, as "to pebble the ice between games"
words.name: Pebble

words.def: A takeout that removes a stone from play as well as the delivered stone. These are usually intentional, such as for blanking an end.
words.name: Peel

words.def: A stone delivered with a heavy takeout weight
words.name: Peel weight

words.def: When a rock's running surface travels over a foreign particle such as a hair, causing the rock to deviate from its expected path, usually by increasing friction and thereby the amount of curl
words.name: Pick

words.def: Spot at the exact centre of the house, officially called the tee.
words.name: Pin

words.def: Competitive play towards club, state/provincial, national, and world championships
words.name: Playdowns

words.def: Another name for a raise; usually means to raise a guard into the house and make it a potential counter
words.name: Promote

words.def: A space between two stones just wide enough for a delivered stone to pass through
words.name: Port

words.def: A shot in which the delivered stone bumps another stone forward
words.name: Raise

words.def: A shot in which the delivered stone bumps a second stone which in turn knocks a third stone out of play. Also called a runback
words.name: Raise takeout

words.def: When a curler considers how the condition of a sheet of ice will influence the path of a thrown stone, similar to how a golfer reads the undulations and texture of a green before determining where and how hard to hit a putt
words.name: Reading the ice

words.def: When a stone is thrown with a particular turn, but it eventually stops and begins to rotate in the opposite direction; usually the result of a pick or poor ice conditions. Sometimes it may even reverse twice in one shot, creating unpredictable shots that follow an S-shaped path.
words.name: Reverse handle

words.def: A call given by the skip to tell the sweepers to neither sweep nor clean the rock; as compared to off!, which tells the sweepers to stop sweeping but not necessarily to stop cleaning
words.name: Right off!

words.def: The house
words.name: Rings

words.def: Slang for the game of curling, it is the sound a stone makes while sliding along the ice
words.name: Roaring Game, The

words.def: The device thrown by curlers during the game. It is made of granite and has a standard weight of 19.6 kg (44 lb). Also called a stone
words.name: Rock

words.def: Any movement of a stone after striking another
words.name: Roll

words.def: Description of a spinning rock
words.name: Rotation

words.def: When a moving stone barely touches another stationary stone; less contact than a chip
words.name: Rub

words.def: A section of the curling sheet that is dipped or troughed that can prevent a stone to curl or draw down its normal path of travel
words.name: Run

words.def: See raise takeout
words.name: Runback

words.def: The part of the rock which comes in contact with the ice. It is about 7 mm wide (0.25 inches)
words.name: Running surface

words.def: See raise takeout
words.name: Runthrough

words.def: A device used by the Ice maker to smooth the ice after a period of extended play; usually performed in conjunction with pebbling
words.name: Scraper

words.def: The Canadian Curling Championships. Also Known as the Scotties Tournament of Hearts
words.name: Scotties

words.def: The player who throws the third and fourth rocks for a team; on most teams they also sweep for all other players on their team
words.name: Second

words.def: The second closest rock to the button
words.name: Second shot

words.def: A wide brush, traditionally made of sheepskin, which is used to clean the ice of any loose debris, typically during the mid-game break (commonly after the 5th end of tournament play)
words.name: Sheepskin

words.def: The area of ice that on which one game is played
words.name: Sheet

words.def: In a hit, refers to the rock being thrown
words.name: Shooter

words.def: The rock in the house closest to the button; the next closest rocks are second shot and third shot. To "be shot" means to have shot rock.
words.name: Shot rock / shot stone

words.def: The curling world championships from 1968–1985
words.name: Silver Broom

words.def: The player who calls the shots and traditionally throws the last two rocks; typically the best player on the team. As a verb, to "skip" means to lead one's rink
words.name: Skip

words.def: The forward movement of a player during the delivery of a stone
words.name: Slide

words.def: A piece of Teflon or similar material attached to a curling shoe that allows the player to slide along the ice
words.name: Slider

words.def: A type of release that makes the rock curl more, usually by imparting less rotation to the handle
words.name: Soft release

words.def: Scots for match, game or competition, this is the term used for a curling competition between members of the same club or community, for example parish spiel; also used as an abbreviation for Bonspiel. Compare Bonspiel.
words.name: Spiel

words.def: A stone traveling with a rapid rotation. Stones thrown in this manner will curl only a small amount, if at all
words.name: Spinner

words.def: A draw shot in which the played stone hits on the side of a stationary stone and both move sideways and stay in play. Not to be confused with split the house
words.name: Split

words.def: A strategy of drawing to a different area of the house to prevent your opponent from taking out both stones
words.name: Split the House

words.def: Slang for socializing with teammates and opponents, often over a drink, after a game
words.name: Stacking the brooms

words.def: Scoring in an end without the hammer
words.name: Steal

words.def: A rock
words.name: Stone

words.def: Synonymous with no handle
words.name: Straight handle

words.def: Ice on which stones curl less than usual
words.name: Straight ice

words.def: a weight that can take out another stone
words.name: Strike weight

words.def: To brush the ice in front of a moving stone, which causes it to travel farther and curl less
words.name: Sweep

words.def: To use the measuring device to determine shot rock
words.name: Swing the stick around

words.def: Ice on which stones curl more than usual
words.name: Swingy ice

words.def: A rock that hits another rock and removes it from play
words.name: Takeout

words.def: The weight required when delivering a stone in order to make a takeout
words.name: Takeout Weight

words.def: Use of the delivery stone to tap another rock towards the back of the house
words.name: Tap back

words.def: The centre point of the house, where the tee line crosses the centre line; the stones' distances from the tee determine the score for each end
words.name: Tee

words.def: The line that goes across the house intersecting with the middle of the button, splitting it into two halves
words.name: Tee line

words.def: The degree of contact between two rocks; the thicker the hit, the more contact between the stones; a hit with a small amount of contact is thin.
words.name: Thick / thin

words.def: The player who throws the fifth and sixth rocks for a team; usually also serves as vice-skip
words.name: Third

words.def: The third closest rock to the button
words.name: Third shot

words.def: A shot that bumps a guard out of the way without removing it from play, to avoid violating the Free Guard Zone Rule; usually played with lead rocks late in a game to prevent the trailing team from setting up a steal
words.name: Tick

words.def: Another term for narrow
words.name: Tight

words.def: At professional levels sweepers use a timer to measure the time between the start of the delivery and the rock hitting the hog line, and will then call out that time as an indicator of the shot's weight. "Time" can also refer to the amount of time left on the game clock
words.name: Time

words.def: The portion of the 4 foot ring in front of the tee line
words.name: Top 4

words.def: The portion of the 8 foot ring in front of the tee line
words.name: Top 8

words.def: The portion of the 12 foot ring in front of the tee line
words.name: Top 12

words.def: The Canadian women's curling championship, held annually since 1982; other women's tournaments were held previously
words.name: Tournament of Hearts

words.def: A flashy but low-percentage shot; also Circus shot
words.name: Trick shot

words.def: A takeout shot in which three other stones are removed from play
words.name: Triple

words.def: An event format where the teams must have two men and two women, played in alternating positions
words.name: True mixed

words.def: Command shouted by a skip – sometimes "off!" or "whoa!" – to tell sweepers to stop sweeping (to bring the brooms "up" off the ice)
words.name: Up!

words.def: The player who discusses strategy with the skip behind the house and holds the broom while the skip throws his rocks; usually plays third; also known as mate
words.name: Vice-Skip or Vice

words.def: The amount of speed with which a rock is delivered; more weight corresponds to a harder throw. When used in a phrase such as "tee-line weight", it refers to the delivery speed required for the rock to come to rest on the tee-line.
words.name: Weight

words.def: A shot where the played stone touches a stationary stone just enough that the played stone changes direction
words.name: Wick

words.def: A stone delivered off the broom to the side away from the desired target, and therefore unlikely to curl far enough to reach it
words.name: Wide

words.def: Synonymous with off
words.name: Whoa!

words.def: A stone that rocks from side to side as it travels because it is not resting on its running surface
words.name: Wobbler

words.def: A missed shot caused by an accidental chip or wick off of another stationary stone
words.name: Wrecked shot
